summary: This is an email from an Assistant U.S. Attorney discussing the status of the non-prosecution agreement with Jeffrey Epstein. The author argues that a binding agreement exists, comprised of the original agreement, a December 19th modification letter, and subsequent correspondence, and cites exchanges with Epstein's attorneys to support this position.

persons.name: Alex Acosta
persons.context: Recipient of the email discussing the Epstein agreement. He is the U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of Florida.

persons.name: Roy Black
persons.context: Epstein's attorney who is being corresponded with regarding the binding nature of the non-prosecution agreement. The author is waiting to hear back from him.

persons.name: Jack Goldberger
persons.context: Epstein's attorney who corresponded about the victim notification document. His July 9, 2008 letter is cited as evidence of assent to the agreement's terms.

persons.name: Jay Lefkowitz
persons.context: Epstein's attorney who was notified via email on June 23, 2008, that the Deputy Attorney General had approved federal prosecution, triggering Epstein's deadline to comply with the agreement.

persons.name: Mike Tein
persons.context: Epstein's attorney present at a meeting in Jack Goldberger's office on June 30, 2008, where the proposed victim notification was delivered.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The subject of the non-prosecution agreement. The document details the government's position that he is bound by an agreement to plead guilty in state court to avoid federal prosecution.

connections.description: Roy Black is identified as one of Epstein's defense attorneys in the correspondence regarding the plea agreement.
Jack Goldberger is identified as one of Epstein's defense attorneys, corresponding with the government on the terms of the victim notification and the agreement.
Jay Lefkowitz is identified as one of Epstein's defense attorneys, who was notified of the DOJ's decision and Epstein's compliance deadline.
Mike Tein is identified as one of Epstein's defense attorneys, present at the meeting where the victim notification was delivered.
Both are attorneys representing Jeffrey Epstein, copied on the same government emails regarding the binding agreement.

events.title: Epstein's Guilty Plea and Sentencing
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein entered a guilty plea and was sentenced in state court, fulfilling a condition of the non-prosecution agreement to avoid federal prosecution.

events.title: Meeting to Deliver Victim Notification
events.description: Government agents and the AUSA met with Epstein's attorneys Jack Goldberger and Mike Tein to provide the proposed 'Notification of Identified Victims' document.

events.title: Notification to Jay Lefkowitz
events.description: The government notified Epstein's attorney Jay Lefkowitz that the Deputy Attorney General had approved federal prosecution, giving Epstein until June 30 to comply with the agreement.

events.title: Goldberger's Letter on Victim Notification
events.description: Jack Goldberger wrote a letter to the AUSA with objections to the proposed victim notification, but his comments are interpreted by the government as written assent to the agreement's conditions.

keyFacts: The U.S. Attorney's Office asserted a binding non-prosecution agreement with Jeffrey Epstein existed prior to his June 30, 2008, guilty plea, comprised of the original agreement, a December 19th modification letter, and subsequent correspondence.
A key condition of the agreement was that identified minor victims would retain the same rights to sue under federal law (18 U.S.C. ยง 2255) as if Epstein had been federally convicted.
The government provided Epstein's attorneys with a list of individuals it was prepared to name as victims in a federal indictment, as part of the agreement's victim notification process.

Epstein's attorney Jack Goldberger's July 9, 2008, correspondence regarding the victim notification is cited by the government as written assent to the terms, strengthening their position that the agreement was operative.
The email reveals internal government concern about consistency, questioning whether it was proper to be 'adamant' pre-plea that an agreement existed but then later question if it was 'operative.'
